title-group.article-title: Mesial Temporal Sclerosis in Children With SCN1A Mutation

contrib.aff: Epilepsy Center Bethesda Children’s Hospital Budapest, Hungary
Epilepsy Center Bethesda Children’s Hospital Budapest, Hungary

body.p: We read with great interest the excellent paper of Van Poppel et al on mesial temporal sclerosis in children with SCN1A mutation. 1 From their 20 patients with SCN1A gene mutation, 6 children had definitive and 4 had possible mesial temporal sclerosis. They concluded that mesial temporal sclerosis is frequent in this population even without previous prolonged febrile seizures.

Van Poppel et al cited our research published in 2005, which found mesial temporal sclerosis in 10 of 14 patients with the clinical diagnosis of Dravet syndrome. 2 Since then, mutation analysis was performed in 8 of these 10 patients and SCN1A gene mutation was found in all of them: 5 missense, 1 frameshift, 1 splice site, and 1 nonsense mutation were found.

More recent papers, however, did not support our findings. A multicenter study of 58 Dravet syndrome patients (35/58 with verified SCN1A mutation) found mesial temporal sclerosis only in 1 patient. 3 Similarly, Korff et al 4 found only 1 case of mesial temporal sclerosis in 16 Dravet syndrome patients (6 of them with SCN1A mutation).

Although we do not know the reason of these different results among neuroimaging assessments of Dravet syndrome patients, the results of Van Poppel et al 1 support the association between mesial temporal sclerosis and SCN1A gene mutation. Their results suggest that this correlation is not simply due to the presence of early prolonged febrile seizures as we hypothesized. Additional assessments and meta-analysis of large patient pools might help clarify if there is causality between gene mutation and mesial temporal sclerosis.
